bibl.title: Letter from Bruce Mayne to Henry Rose Carter, September 13, 1919

div1.p: Mayne discusses hyperparasitism and mosquito experimentation.

div1.head: Letter from Bruce Mayne to Henry Rose Carter, September 13, 1919
div1.opener:
F.
Mal.
SaMayne
MANUEL GAYOSO
HOTEL GAYOSO
MEMPHIS HOTEL COMPANY
PROPRIETORS
MEMPHIS Sept 13 1919
My dear Doctor Carter,
div1.p:
Relative to the question
of Sambon's theory of hyperparasitism
I am reminded that I made
a special effort to obtain
first hand information while
attending the courses at the
Tropical School in London.
I recall a lecture by Dr. Sambon
in which he announced for the
first time definitely his interesting
theory stating that Sir Patrick had
2
MANUEL GAYOSO
HOTEL GAYOSO
MEMPHIS HOTEL COMPANY
PROPRIETORS
MEMPHIS ____ 19____
accepted the principle and would
give Sambon credit in his new
edition of “Tropical Diseases” then
in press.

About this time I received a
letter from von Ezdorf requesting
me to interview Sambon and gain
first hand impression of hyper-
parasitism relative to mosquito
infectivity. I spent several hours
with Sambon discussing
mosquito experimentation and
hyperparasitism especially. Whilst
3
MANUEL GAYOSO
HOTEL GAYOSO
MEMPHIS HOTEL COMPANY
PROPRIETORS
MEMPHIS ____ 19____
at his home I was shown
some beautiful sketches of
mosquito parasites, particularly
Noserno. Incidentally, Sambon
showed me an unpublished sketch
of plasmodial infection of the eggs
of Anopheles. I remember advising
him not to publish his ideas
on hereditary infection until he
had been able to demonstrate
more permanent viability through
the various stages, inasmuch as
4
MANUEL GAYOSO
HOTEL GAYOSO
MEMPHIS HOTEL COMPANY
PROPRIETORS
MEMPHIS ____ 19____
his evidence was based almost
wholly on morphology.

I am beginning to appreciate
that punctipennis is not easily
infected experimentally. So far
this species (from Shelly County)
has proven unsusceptible to
both vivax and falciparum.
Unfortunately this County has not
produced a sufficient number of
quads for comparative study.
